English_Strict: Culicidae. In some cases it can be that pernilongo and mosquito are referring to different genera of the family Culicidae (Culex and Aedes respectively).
Ceratopogonidae ; This is a potentially misleading common term in english. Outside the US it probably refers to Diptera: Psychodidae: Phlebotominae

French: criquet (suborder Caelifera), sauterelle (suborder Ensifera) (NCP: the subordere Ensifera are katydids or bush crickets, but occasionally the common name sauterelle is used for the suborder Caelifera too)

English_Strict: Orthoptera: Ensifera (common names: katydids, bush crickets)
The english term is for any small parrot really. Put any small parrots you find in here and we are going to separate them out later.
Chilopoda. They bite and have venom. Also have less legs than a millipede (1 pair of legs for each segment). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centipede
French: scolopendre, mille pattes (NCP: mille pattes can refer to both centipedes and millipedes), chilopodes, centipèdes

English_Strict: Diplopoda. They are harmless. They curl up to defend themselves. They have 2 pairs of legs at each segment. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millipede
French: mille-pattes (NCP: mille pattes can refer to both centipedes and millipedes), diplopode

English_Strict: The verb name is in the lax row. (We initially had a meaning name (v) glossed in Spanish and Portuguese as llamar and chamar, the exact same glosses for call. Most of the items in the old name (v) meaning were identical with call, and were moved there. The ones that were not identical were moved in the lax row here with name (v) as their gloss. Their original gloss could be llamar or chamar and they could actually mean call and not name, but we need to look at the original source for that)
Items from old dirty, soil (v) row are here
